facts.text: Appellants are owners of a building on Dashaswamedh Road in Varanasi, ground floor consisted of two shops separated by a partition wall and an arch.
Respondent was tenant of one shop; adjacent shop let to Benarsidas Lohar who vacated.
With sanction of Rent Control Officer, adjacent shop let to respondent as from July 24, 1954.
On July 21, 1954, respondent executed rent note agreeing no right to make alterations, additions, or repairs.
Respondent took possession of both shops.
On August 8, 1954, appellants at respondent's request removed partition wall and replaced arch with iron girders.
About mid-October 1954, respondent started making alterations without appellants' consent.
Appellants objected by telegram and letters.
Notice dated February 22, 1955 terminating tenancy and demanding possession.
Appellants filed suit for ejectment claiming alterations were material, entitling eviction without District Magistrate permission.
Alterations: lowering floor level by 1.5 ft by excavating earth and new floor; lowering front door entailing cutting plinthband; lowering staircase level and new steps; lowering Chabutra height.
Trial Judge and First Additional Civil Judge, Varanasi found alterations material without consent, decreed eviction.
Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 90 of 1959 (judgment January 17, 1961) accepted alterations without consent and material but reversed on interpretation of s.3(1)(c), dismissed suit.

legal_issues.text: Interpretation of s.3(1)(c) of U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, III of 1947: whether 'materially altered the accommodation or is likely substantially to diminish its value' is disjunctive or conjunctive.
Whether alterations carried out by respondent-tenant materially altered the accommodation within meaning of s.3(1)(c).

petitioner_arguments.text: Clause (c) is disjunctive: applies if alterations materially alter OR likely to diminish value substantially.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.3(1)(c) U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, III of 1947
s.3(1)(c) U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, III of 1947

respondent_arguments.text: 'or' in clause (c) should be read as 'and'; must establish both material alteration AND substantial diminution of value.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3(1)(c) U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, III of 1947

respondent_arguments.text: Alterations enhanced value and were not material.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3(1)(c) U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, III of 1947

court_reasoning.text: Clause (c) in simple unambiguous language; disjunctive: material alteration OR likely to diminish value; ordinary construction unless absurdity.
Alterations materially altered accommodation: changed form and structure (lowering floor 1.5 ft, door, staircase, Chabutra).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Structural alterations giving new face to premises.

court_reasoning.text: Hymen v. Rose distinguished (forfeiture relief, different context); Wates v. Rowland and Bickomore v. Dimmer illustrate structural alterations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Material alterations need not damage or diminish value.

holdings.text: s.3(1)(c) disjunctive; material alterations suffice for eviction without permission.
Respondent's alterations were material, entitling appellants to eviction decree.

precedents_cited.relevance: Relief against forfeiture; alterations did not harm; different context of lease covenant and waste.
Illustration of structural alteration vs. repairs under similar rent act provision.
Distinction between minor changes and material alterations changing form or structure.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, III of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Ground for eviction without District Magistrate permission if tenant makes material alterations or those diminishing value without landlord consent.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and decree set aside; judgment and decree of First Additional Civil Judge, Varanasi restored directing eviction of respondent.
outcome.costs: Respondent to pay appellants' costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "the clause is couched in simple and unambiguous language and in its plain meaning provides that it would be a good ground... if the tenant has made... such construction which materially alters the accommodation or is likely substantially to diminish its value."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of s.3(1)(c) as disjunctive.

key_quotes.text: "The expression material alterations in its ordinary meaning would mean important alterations, such as those which materially or substantially change the front or the structure of the premises."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Low[er]ing the level of the ground floor by about 1-1/2 ft.... are clearly structural alterations which... give a new face to the form and structure of the premises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies to facts, holds alterations material.
